# Hexo ç½‘ç«™æ­å»ºæŒ‡å—

Welcome to [Hexo](https://hexo.io/)! 

This is a Guideline of building your own hexo, which is written in English, but easy to understand!

## æ­å»ºå‰çš„å‡†å¤‡

### Git Installation

- Linux/Mac:

```bash
sudo apt install git
```

- Windows:

Official link: [Download git](https://gitforwindows.org/)

- Check whether installed or not:

```bash
git --version
```

### Nodejs Installation

- Linux/Mac:

```bash
sudo apt install nodejs
sudo aot install npm
```

- Windows:

Official link: [nodejs](https://nodejs.org/en/download/) (Suggest you to choose LTS version)

- Check whether installed or not:

```bash
node -v
npm -v
```

### Hexo Installation

- Linux/Mac:

```bash
sudo npm install -g hexo-cli
```

- Windows:

```bash
npm install -g hexo-cli
```

- Check whether installed or not:

```bash
hexo -v
```

## éƒ¨ç½²æœ¬åœ°Hexoç½‘ç«™

â€‹		First you need to **choose or create a folder** to storage the local hexo website. For instance, in `C:/Software/My_Hexo`.

â€‹		Then right click the folder, click `open in Windows terminal`; or just use command line to get into that folder.

```bash
sudo hexo init Mybolg
ls Myblog
sudo npm install
```

â€‹		*Note that you can replace `Mybolg` into any word you like.

â€‹		Now you can see some files inside the folder, but only three folders you need to concerntrated.

- node_modules: ä¾èµ–åŒ…
- publicï¼šå­˜æ”¾ç”Ÿæˆçš„é¡µé¢
- scaffoldsï¼šç”Ÿæˆæ–‡ç« çš„ä¸€äº›æ¨¡æ¿
- ==source==ï¼šä½ çš„æ–‡ç« å’Œç´ ææ”¾åœ¨è¿™é‡Œ
- ==themes==ï¼šå­—é¢æ„æ€
- ==_config.yml==: åšå®¢çš„é…ç½®æ–‡ä»¶

## ä½¿ç”¨Githubæ‰˜ç®¡ç½‘é¡µ

### Create a new repository on Github

â€‹		Firstly, you need to have a github accountâ€¦

â€‹		Then, create a **new repository** on github and named `yourusername.github.io`, note that you **must** named like this (`yourusername` is your user name), otherwise the deployment cannot be reconigzed. 

### Add SSH key to Github

â€‹		Back to the terminal, generate the SSH and add it into github so that github can know whether the your computer are visiting the corresponding account.

```bash
git cofig --global user.name "yourusername"
git cofig --global user.email "youremail"
ssh-keygen -t rsa -C "youremail"
```

â€‹		The computer then will tell you the path of `.ssh`, find it on your computer, and open it via notepad.

â€‹		To say it simpler, ssh is just the ID of your computer, github recogized your computer via this ID. `id_rsa` is your private key that you cannot show it to others, while `id_rsa.pub` is the public key, you can copy the info to github.

â€‹		`Github -> settings -> personal settings -> SSH and PGP keys -> New SSH key`

â€‹		You can verify whether add the SSH key successfully via your terminal:

```bash
ssh -T git@github.com
```

   ### Deploy hexo to Github

â€‹		Open your folder, remember the three folders that I let you to conceretrate? Now it truns into `_config.yml` file, open it and add something in the end:

```bash
deploy:
  type: git
  repo: https://github.com/yourusername/yourusername.github.io.git
  branch: master
```

â€‹		*Notice the format must be totally same with me, pay attention to the **blanks**.

â€‹		Before deployment, you need to install the `deploy-git` in your computer so that you can deploy your own hexo into github.

```bash
sudo npm install hexo-deployer-git --save
```

â€‹		Finally, deploy your website via the following commands, and you can visit your bolg via `http://yourusername.github.io`.

```bash
hexo clean
hexo deploy
hexo generate
```

## ä¸Šä¼ ä½ çš„ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæ–‡ç« 

### Create a new post

``` bash
hexo new "My New Post"
```

More info: [Writing](https://hexo.io/docs/writing.html)

### Run server

``` bash
hexo server
```

More info: [Server](https://hexo.io/docs/server.html)

### Generate static files

``` bash
hexo generate
```

More info: [Generating](https://hexo.io/docs/generating.html)

### Deploy to remote sites

``` bash
hexo deploy
```

More info: [Deployment](https://hexo.io/docs/one-command-deployment.html)

### Advanced Settings

Create a bat format file (e.g. `start.bat`) in the root folder of your blog.

```bash
hexo clean & hexo d & hexo g & hexo s
pause
```

Then every time you uploaded a file or change any settings, you can just double click the .bat file to update your blog, which is very convenience.

---

void InOrderTraverse(BiTree root)

void PostOrder(BiTree Root)

    while (!s.empty())

        }

{

#include<iostream>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
struct TreeNode {
...};
class Solution {
public:
    int arr[7] = { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, NULL, 6 };
    void inorder(TreeNode* root, vector<int>& res)//ä¸­åºéå†
    {
        if (root == nullptr)
            return;

        inorder(root->left, res);
        res.push_back(root->val);
        inorder(root->right, res);
    }
    vector<int> inorderTraversal(TreeNode* root)//é€’å½’æ³•
    {
        vector<int> ans;
        inorder(root, ans);
        return ans;
    }
    vector<int> inorderTraversal(TreeNode* root)//è¿­ä»£æ³•
    {
        vector<int> ans;
        stack<TreeNode*> stk;
           
        while (1)
        {
            if (root != nullptr)
            {
                stk.push(root);
                root = root->left;
            }
            else if (!stk.empty())
            {
                root = stk.top();
                stk.pop();
                ans.push_back(root->val);
                root = root->right;
            }
            else
                return ans;
        }
        
    }
    TreeNode* addtree(TreeNode* tree, int arr[], int i)//æ•°ç»„è½¬é“¾è¡¨
    {
        if (arr[i] == 0)
            return NULL;
        if (i < 7)//arr.length()
        {
            TreeNode* tree = new TreeNode();
            
            tree->val = arr[i];
            tree->left = addtree(tree, arr, i + i + 1);
            tree->right = addtree(tree, arr, i + i + 2);
            return tree;
        }
        return NULL;
    }
};

int main()
{
    Solution sol;
    TreeNode* tree = NULL;
    tree= sol.addtree(tree, sol.arr, 0);
    sol.inorderTraversal(tree);
    for(int i= 0; i< sol.inorderTraversal(tree).size(); i++)
        cout << sol.inorderTraversal(tree)[i]<<" ";
    return 0;
}
